DOC.HEAD: Scientists Challenge Administration View on Plutonium Needs
Eds: Subs 3rd graf, The Energy Department, with department comment
DOC.TEXT: The United States has plenty of plutonium for future use in nuclear weapons, and the Bush administration should drop plans to spend $1 billion to expand supplies of the material, a government advisory panel concludes. The conclusion published Wednesday by a special committee of the National Research Council contradicts the administration's repeated assertions to Congress that additional capacity to make weapon-grade plutonium is vital to national security. The Energy Department, which owns the nation's defense nuclear materials plants, issued a brief statement saying it had not fully analyzed the document but would respond in detail within 30 days. It said the report's recommendations ``appear to to fully consistent with and supportive of'' actions already taken or planned by the department. Former Energy Secretary John Herrington said during the Reagan administration that the nation is ``awash in plutonium,'' but his successor, James D. Watkins, had disavowed the statement. Watkins contends that while current plutonium supplies are adequate, more capacity will be needed in the coming decade. The research council said it saw no good reason either to produce more virgin plutonium or to increase the capacity for processing recycled plutonium from old weapons. It also challenged Watkins' plan to build a $600 million plant in Idaho that would convert reactor-grade plutonium to weapon-grade material. ``The Department of Energy should concentrate on making better use of existing plutonium processing capacity as required and postpone plans to construct additional capabilities,'' the report said. Many private arms control groups have long advocated scaling back plutonium operations. ``This is a certification by a semi-official body that you don't need'' additional plutonium supplies, said David Albright, senior staff scientist of the Federation of American Scientists. The report also criticized some aspects of the Energy Department's overall management of the weapons complex, which includes 17 major plants and laboratories in 12 states. On the subject of plutonium, the report noted that the United States already has more than 20,000 nuclear weapons. ``The plutonium in these devices, plus that in the supply chain, is obviously sufficient to supply a nuclear deterrent of the existing size or even greater,'' it said. Official information on nuclear arms materials is classified. Watkins has advocated building a Special Isotope Separation plant at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Falls. It would use a new vaporizing technology to convert reactor-grade plutonium now stored near Richland, Wash., into plutonium suitable for use in nuclear weapons. The scientific panel cited several reasons for scrapping the Idaho project. ``To our knowledge, no compelling need for this material has been demonstrated,'' its report said. It also said the Idaho facility, if built, could complicate international efforts to limit the spread of nuclear arms. The new isotope separation technology could be obtained by other countries to convert fuel used in civilian nuclear reactors into high-grade plutonium needed to build nuclear bombs, it said. John Spratt, D-S.C., chairman of a special House committee on defense nuclear facilities, said in a telephone interview that the report's conclusion about plutonium supplies, combined with congressional resistance to adding more capacity, make it ``very unlikely that the Special Isotope Separation plant will be built.'' The report also said the Energy Department should drop plans to spend $400 million renovating a building at the Rocky Flats plant near Denver that recycles scrap plutonium into weapons-grade material. The research council is an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, a congressionally chartered group that conducts special research at the request of the government.
